pros: MCAD has an amazing community full of very talented and kind people, from the staff to the faculty to, of course, the students.
Respectful colleagues. Flexible work schedule. Great benefits.
cons: Lower pay- small, non profit cannot pay what larger universities can.

pros: Friendly, creative, invigorating projects, and in the heart of Minneapolis.
cons: Top heavy management, poor pay equity, and demanding work load.

review_title: Good to keep afloat in school
job_title: Work Study Student in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Media Center Job was one of the best I ever had, and the wage was livable as a student for rent and groceries. Great opportunity for me at the time.

review_title: Competitive Amenities for a very Non-Competitive Salary
pros: flexible, cool environment, lots of vacation time, good work life balance, only 35 hr work weeks
cons: pay isn't great, not a lot of room for upward movement, not a lot of professional development

review_title: Great Place with A Few Hiccups
pros:
I absolutely love working at MCAD. I had fantastic work/life balance, and my coworkers were a delight.

I worked under the former MCAD President, so I'm not sure how things have changed since the new President took charge.

That said, if they were able to offer a better compensation package, I'd go back in a heartbeat.
cons:
Being a nonprofit, and an art school, there isn't much in the way of salary. If they had been able to pay more or offer a clearer path for advancement, I would have loved to stay.

I also heard tell of some tricky inner-politics. I wasn't high enough up to know all that was going on, but I know there was some general frustration.

pros: Loved working at MCAD. I was a remote notetaker/access assistant.
cons: Only being scheduled a couple of times a week/when needed.

job_title: Social Media Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
cons: Nothing to say here to be honest.

review_title: Inspiring environment, high concentration of talented people, but limited support
pros: MCAD is a very special place filled with people with fascinating ideas and impressive skills in a variety of areas. The faculty and students are doing great things, but dig a little deeper and you find that most people on staff, from security guards to shop technicians to admin assistants, have thriving artistic practices outside of their day jobs.
cons: HR and upper administration are out of touch with the school's mission and the big picture. Very talented people choose to leave the college due to lack of support. There is an unhealthy hierarchy and lack of cooperation between upper administration, faculty, and staff.

pros: Love art? This is a fantastic place to work in that you will be surrounded by art and artists at all times. Employees are fun to be around; mostly professionals in their 30s-40s. They seem to enjoy their jobs. Excellent location in South Minneapolis; beautiful campus. Tuition waiver.
cons: Some cons are: high cost of benefits, lack of diversity, cost per credit. It's hard to back a college that will most likely leave students with lots of debt. The college is small, so there isn't much room for advancement.

pros: Committed students with a drive for creativity and pushing boundaries (in a healthy way).
cons: I found that as an adjunct I could have benefited from more support from the college. It took two years to settle in and feel like I was adding value. That time frame could have been reduced with more support and/or coordination and connection with more experienced adjuncts.

pros:
generous vacation/ sick package, 35 hour week
stimulating visual environment
cons:
lack of leadership
fearful micromanaging
lack of promotion/salary increase
lack of alignment to mission, values and vision
lack of acknowledgement and recognition of staff and faculty 
lack of creative problem solving

pros: Steady work, great co-workers, convenient location
cons: Not compensated well for my odd schedule and time, got paid less than new hires with less experience.

pros: My coworkers were great and working for a non profit is nice.
cons: The management was poor, very unfriendly with staff and students, lots of yelling.

job_title: Adjunct Art Instructor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Little to know interference with my lessons from tenured faculty.  The students are very talented.  Inspiring work environment.
cons: Not full time and low pay

review_title: Not invested in adjunct professional development
pros: Creative culture, amazing peer educators, great facilities
cons: Very political, often antiquated, not invested in growing qualified educators

pros: Can set your own hours, easy going
cons: Hard to get students to follow up with you
